10.1051/kmae/2025018.abstract: <jats:p>Hydropower is a vital renewable energy source but has substantial ecological impacts on rivers, lakes, and surrounding ecosystems. It alters hydrogeomorphology, disrupts connectivity, and changes water physicochemical properties such as temperature and dissolved gas concentrations. Historically, the environmental impact has been of less concern compared to energy production, and there is an urgent need to adapt hydropower production to reduce impacts on aquatic ecosystems. While various mitigation measures exist, a systematic understanding of their efficiency is lacking. Here, we extensively review both the environmental effects of hydropower and the scientific base for mitigation measures. We then list key abiotic and biological candidates for systematic monitoring before outlining a programmatic monitoring approach to evaluate the efficiency of mitigation measures. This programmatic monitoring approach involves monitoring packages based on specific mitigation measures. A set of abiotic parameters and biological indicators are monitored with standardized methods and monitoring designs over the long-term and at several sites, covering different river types and hydropower configurations. The proposed program serves to inform ongoing and future remedial measures, expand our mechanistic understanding of the ecological effects, facilitate knowledge transfer, and allow for more reductionist monitoring approaches outside of the program.</jats:p>
title: Balancing hydropower production and ecology − ecological impacts, mitigation measures, and programmatic monitoring

user_notes.text: has an important role in the large sustainable and green global energy transition. Renewable energy systems have been attracting substantial economic, environmental, and technical attention throughout the last decade, while some have been in the market for almost a century. However, even renewable

The lasting overall environmental and social impacts of large hydropower have increasingly made the costs unacceptable and consequently, more dams are nowadays removed than built in North America and Europe

funder.name: Schweizerischer Nationalfonds zur Förderung der Wissenschaftlichen Forschung

10.1111/1365-2664.70075.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>
<jats:list>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>In efforts to curb global CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> emissions, energy production sees massive transformations worldwide—away from fossil‐fuel to renewable power generation.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>However, the construction and operation of renewable energy infrastructure alters landscapes and habitats on this global scale and may have a range of environmental and ecological impacts on species, populations, biodiversity and ultimately, ecosystem services and disservices. As the climate and biodiversity crisis are two of the greatest challenges of our time, and both are interlinked, we need to consider biodiversity costs in gains from transitioning to net‐zero and conversely, costs of the energy transition in terms of loss of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p>This Special Feature includes works that address current questions as to the implications of new energy infrastructure for biodiversity, identify trade‐offs for balancing contrasting aims of energy production and biodiversity conservation, and propose mitigation measures for potentially harmful effects.</jats:p></jats:list-item>

<jats:list-item><jats:p><jats:italic>Synthesis and applications</jats:italic>. Combining the goals of energy transition and biodiversity protection is both necessary and possible. With the costs of inaction increasing rapidly, we need to remember that combatting climate change (through the energy transition) is an important element in halting biodiversity loss (through climate change). Still, some questions remain as to the net effects of globally upscaled use of renewable energy production on biodiversity and whether scalable mitigation measures for these costs will be sufficiently effective.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list>
</jats:p>
title: Towards a sustainable energy transition
